UTEID: jm76685;
FIRSTNAME: Jonathan;
LASTNAME: Madden;
CSACCOUNT: jm76685;
EMAIL: jm76685@cs.utexas.edu;

[Program 4]
[Description]
There are 2 java files: In Encoder.java, The most important methods are decodeFile and encodeFile. The method decodeFile
uses the mappings of encryptions to characters to interpret the file one line at a time. The method encodeFile uses the 
mappings of characters to encryptions to write out a file of encodings. All of the other methods are for creating the Huffman
codes used for the mappings or for generating a random string of text.
In Node.java, this is the data structure used for the huffman tree. This is taken from  
http://cs.smith.edu/dftwiki/index.php/CSC212_Huffman_Ecoding_in_Java.
To compile our program, you need to use "javac Encoder.java". To run our program, you need to use 
java Encoder frequenciesFile k, where frequenciesFile is the name of a file containing integers representing the relative 
frequencies of characters in the alphabet (as described in the first step above), and k is a positive integer that tells 
how many characters to generate (according to that probability distribution).

[Finish]
I finished all of the project

[Test Case 1]
[Command line]
java Encoder frequenciesFile 4

[Input]
4
3
2
1

[Output]
Entropy: 1.8464393446710154

Encodings
A 0
B 10
C 111
D 110

Efficiency: 1.0398391940365044  bitAvg: 1.92

2 symbol Encodings
AA 001
DD 10000
BB 1100
CC 11101
AB 000
BC 1010
CD 11100
BD 0100
AC 1011
AD 1001
DA 0110
DB 0101
CA 1101
CB 0111
DC 10001
BA 1111

Efficiency2: 1.0290075357652908  bitAvg: 1.9
